Heyy as a student and 2 time SME of PESU I/O here's my review  
1. Go for a non-technical courses, you'll be able to learn from a senior and also find peers with similar interest  
2. For Technical courses, it really depends on the senior who is your SME and his proficiency in the subject and his teaching skills   
3. If the course is paid (idk if things have changed) then i would suggest to look somewhere outside for technical courses, the certification issuing organization does matter  
4. PESU I/O acts like a brilliant space to network and meet like minded peeps, that's a experience worth joining PESU I/O  
5. If possible, in your 4 years of college, try becoming and SME too, it will teach you good things and you'll probably enjoy it  


Is it worth it?  
For technical courses, i mostly think No; but for non-technical courses, definitely

I'd like to add to that...if you're looking to get into dev, it really gives you that starting point, because everybody around you is developing something so you will have the urge to do smtn better too. 

I took up a flutter course in my 2nd sem and after that course took things forward to build some projects out of that.

Very simple as stated...

1. PESU IO is something which gives you an opening for the things which is not in college curriculum. 
2. It is more comfortable to learn with a peer and a senior than to learn than learning using tutorial.
3. Since it is for a short duration, it kinda gives a quick exposure to certain topics.. If you are not interested, then topic change.. course change
4. I got a few seniors who helped me through-out my PESU life.. That was through PESU IO.
5. PESU IO core team handles tier 1 events (except Aatmatrisha - That is mostly who stick with VK for years).. Events like TAS, Epsilon Selection etc. If you showcase your skills.. then it's a gateway for great things
6. Courses will be comparately good and kinda worth for the money. They give some college branded goodies as well

Cons:

1. All the classes are post college hours. Need to make some time for assignments and projects.
2. Sometimes heavy concepts will be taught by the SMEs. For newbies, it might be difficult to pick-up. Only solution is to talk it out and work a lil more.
3. You will be exposed for the topic for a short time.. Most of us, tend to leave it there.. A continous learning timeline is our responsibility. Few SMEs will be kind enough to hold our hands till the end....

If you ask me.. Go for it.. Have something which other college students won't be having. The certificates are valid outside only.. It is handy during internship application, but what matters more is.. what you have picked up in the PESU IO Course. Most of the clubs like Hackerspace, IEEE etc tried to implement/copy this.. A lot of discussions also happened. But PESU IO is kinda doing it from 2017 (My first year in PESU) and they have developed this at some next level.

I've taken two courses and both seemed totally worth it to me. I noticed people saying they'd rather take a udemy course but let's be honest, you won't get the one to one interaction, offline sessions or the group project experience in online courses. It's an excellent place to start exploring since most first years won't be sure where their interest lies. So I'd surely recommend taking a course.
